etymologies: Old English and, ond, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch en and German und

notes.text: It is still widely taught and believed that conjunctions such as and (and also but and because) should not be used to start a sentence, the argument being that a sentence starting with and expresses an incomplete thought and is therefore incorrect. Writers down the centuries have readily ignored this advice, however, using and to start a sentence, typically for rhetorical effect, as in the following example: What are the government's chances of winning in court? And what are the consequences? A small number of verbs, notably try, come, and go can be followed by and with another verb, as in sentences like we're going to try and explain it to them or why don't you come and see the film? The structures in these verbs correspond to the use of the infinitive to, as in we're going to try to explain it to them or why don't you come to see the film? Since these structures are grammatically odd—for example, the use is normally only idiomatic with the infinitive of the verb and not with other forms (i.e. it is not possible to say I tried and explained it to them)—they are regarded as wrong by some traditionalists. However, these uses are extremely common and can certainly be regarded as part of standard English. For information about whether it is more correct to say both the boys and the girls or both the boys and girls, see both

definitions: used to connect words of the same part of speech, clauses, or sentences, that are to be taken jointly
short_definitions: used to connect words of same part of speech, clauses, or sentences

definitions: used to connect two clauses when the second refers to something that happens after the first

examples.text: he turned round and walked out

short_definitions: used to connect two clauses when second refers to something that happens after first

definitions: used to connect two clauses, the second of which refers to something that results from the first

examples.text: there was a flash flood and by the next morning the town was under water

short_definitions: used to connect two clauses, second of which refers to something that results from first

definitions: connecting two identical comparatives, to emphasize a progressive change
short_definitions: connecting two identical comparatives, to emphasize progressive change

definitions: connecting two identical words, implying great duration or great extent
short_definitions: connecting two identical words, implying great duration

definitions: used to connect two identical words to indicate that things of the same name or class have different qualities

examples.text: all human conduct is determined or caused—but there are causes and causes

short_definitions: used to connect two identical words to indicate that things of same name or class have different qualities

definitions: used to connect two numbers to indicate that they are being added together
short_definitions: used to connect two numbers to indicate that they are being added together

definitions: used to connect two numbers, implying succession

examples.text: a line of men marching two and two

short_definitions: used to connect two numbers, implying succession

definitions: used to introduce an additional comment or interjection

examples.text: if it came to a choice—and this was the worst thing—she would turn her back on her parents

short_definitions: used to introduce additional comment or interjection

definitions: used to introduce a question in connection with what someone else has just said

examples.text: ‘I found the letter in her bag.’ ‘And did you steam it open?’

short_definitions: used to introduce question in connection with what someone else has just said

definitions: used to introduce a statement about a new topic
short_definitions: used to introduce statement about new topic

definitions: used after some verbs and before another verb to indicate intention, instead of ‘to’

examples.text: I would try and do what he said

short_definitions: used after some verbs and before another verb to indicate intention, instead of 'to'

notes.text: It is still widely taught and believed that conjunctions such as and (and also but and because) should not be used to start a sentence, the argument being that a sentence starting with and expresses an incomplete thought and is therefore incorrect. Writers down the centuries have readily ignored this advice, however, using and to start a sentence, typically for rhetorical effect, as in the following example: What are the government's chances of winning in court? And what are the consequences? A small number of verbs, notably try, come, and go can be followed by and with another verb, as in sentences like we're going to try and explain it to them or why don't you come and see the film? The structures in these verbs correspond to the use of the infinitive to, as in we're going to try to explain it to them or why don't you come to see the film? Since these structures are grammatically odd—for example, the use is normally only idiomatic with the infinitive of the verb and not with other forms (i.e. it is not possible to say I tried and explained it to them)—they are regarded as wrong by some traditionalists. However, these uses are extremely common and can certainly be regarded as part of standard English. For information about whether it is more correct to say both the boys and the girls or both the boys and girls, see both

definitions: a Boolean operator which gives the value one if and only if all the operands are one, and otherwise has a value of zero.
short_definitions: Boolean operator which gives value one if and only if all operands are one, and otherwise has value of zero

definitions: a circuit which produces an output signal only when signals are received simultaneously through all input connections.
short_definitions: circuit which produces output signal only when signals are received simultaneously through all input connections
